To be clear, I’m very bullish ETH and L2s. I think they’re definitely the consensus bet to win right now 

Solana undeniably has its issues, but just addressing some of the more disingenuous narratives I’ve seen floating around lately

Regarding centralisation, I think it’s hard to deny that L2s in their current form are far more centralised than Solana 

Single sequencers, no permissionless proofs in production, multisigs, and a bunch of other training wheels which will slowly come off over the next few years

Assuming you believed in your project, in 2018/2019 your options were ride or die. You either made it work on Ethereum or you quit the project altogether, since there weren't really any legitimate alternative L1s

Nowadays, the calculus is very different

Many compare Solana's current trials to what the Eth community went through in the 2018 bear market

A vast array of different individuals and companies participate in this industry in an effort to influence the direction of regulations which affect their interests 

I see the same thing happening for tokens which govern systemically important crypto networks/services
A good proxy for the value of governance divorced from direct cashflows might be the lobbying industry in the US (~$9b according to some analysts)

For a crypto example of this, if the Metamask governance token allowed you to vote on direction of development (e.g. which non-EVM chain they support first), this would clearly be valuable even absent swap fees

Open Source - Determining the direction of scarce development resources of widely used digital infrastructure is valuable even absent cashflows. Some argue this is why big cos donate so much $ to OSS

https://t.co/ob9BflOQsm

App Store - Governing app store review policy would clearly be valuable even if the app store itself didn’t capture any fees

In both these cases, you're affecting the cashflows of the many businesses which leverage these platforms to sell services / broadcast messages
Social Media – Determining the news feed algorithm for large social media platforms like FB/IG/Twitter would be valuable even if these projects didn’t generate a dollar of ad revenue

Disagree w/ this take 

Imo, governance of a thing can be valuable even if the thing being governed doesn't generate cashflows directly, as long as it indirectly affects the cashflows of underlying projects that benefit from or leverage it in some way 

A few examples:

21/ There are some complexities to implementation and some optimisations that could be made, but curious to get people's high-level thoughts on this 

@Injective_ @SeiNetwork @Neutron_org @archwayHQ @zmanian @stablekwon @sunnya97 @lex_node @larry0x @tracheopteryx @ianDAOs

20/ For instance, the matching ratio for a nascent ecosystem could start off very high to compensate for the risk of building there, gradually reducing over time as the ecosystem becomes more attractive to build on its own right

19/ Matching ratio as a lever

The matching ratio determines the magnitude of the subsidy given to builders/investors in that ecosystem. This can be used as a lever to differentially incentivise builders at different stages of the ecosystem's development

18/ Free market vs central planning

Rather than either a DAO or a small committee deciding what is worth funding, this is effectively outsourced to the free market.

17/ No governance proposals required 

Projects no longer need to spend time producing governance proposals and engaging in protracted forum discussions with DAO members. Instead, they can simply raise funding, validate this funding and receive matching from the DAO

16/ Specifically, it should incentivise them to expend the minimum amount of time politiquing to guarantee their vesting doesn't get cancelled. 

It also gives projects a meaningful stake in the L1 ecosystem they're building on, further aligning incentives.

15/ Incentive alignment 

Firstly, it makes the projects accountable to governance (i.e. L1 tokenholders), incentivising them to be transparent about what they're building and how it adds value to the ecosystem.

14/ Funding is provided in the native token and vested over 4 years, with the vesting being cancellable via governance vote at any time. 

This has several benefits.

13/ Allocation by free market matching (inspired by @gitcoin )

Projects independently raise funding to build some product, committing to a given L1 ecosystem

The L1 community fund then provides matching funding at some multiple of the amount raised (matching ratio)

12/ Allocation by committee

Electing a committee to act as an ecosystem VC fund is an interesting idea. However, it seems unlikely to be able to attract the best talent. Why would the best analysts/investors go work for a DAO instead of a large fund w/ carry incentives?

11/ The projects which are loudest / better at lobbying will end up capturing the majority of the funding

In my experience there's little overlap between people who are good at politiquing and people who are good at actually building/investing

10/ Allocating by governance proposals 

I don't think it's possible to successfully allocate capital via a decentralised governance process. Doing so will result in massive overhead costs as the ecosystem gets captured by armies of full-time bureaucrats arguing on forums

9/ More fundamentally: whatever can be gamed, will be gamed. As Goodhart's law illustrates: "when a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure"

There's a reason VCs dont invest purely based on metrics.

https://t.co/5gO9mrb8cw
8/ TVL obviously doesn't reflect the value a project adds to an ecosystem. Adding more nuanced off-chain metrics like DAUs might help, but this introduces data quality/oracle problems

7/ Allocation by objective metric 

This involves deterministically allocating incentives based on some (ideally on-chain) metric. In the original Terra Rebirth proposal, the metric selected was TVL https://t.co/3NYqovAkOP
6/ I'll quickly go over what these are and their flaws, before suggesting an alternative solution which I'm temporarily calling "Free Market Matching"

5/ There are a few ways that have been suggested for DAOs to tackle this capital allocation problem: 

allocation by objective metrics
allocation by governance proposal
allocation by committee.
4/ The difficulty is identifying which projects to fund to achieve these goals. This is essentially a capital allocation problem and as many have recently discovered, VC is a hard business

3/ This is similar to what VCs do, but unlike traditional VC which aims to maximise returns, the community fund has a more abstract goal which can be seen as a mixture of things including increasing liquidity in the ecosystem, brand awareness, user growth, better dev tooling, etc
2/ Ultimately, the goal of developer mining should be to subsidise projects that will help grow the ecosystem and maximise returns to L1 tokenholders

1/ @terra_money is struggling w/ this rn, as evidenced by the Terra Expedition proposal and ensuing debate

Disadvantages: large liquidations may destroy OB liquidity. But this is a similar scenario to not getting enough participation in an on-chain liquidation auction, with similarly bad consequences 

Thoughts?

Unlike the previous Kujira mechanism on Terra which delayed bids, this still allows sophisticated liquidators to come in and bid on liquidations via limit orders on OB

Seems like best of both worlds where you allow both passive and active liquidity to participate

Idea for liquidation mechanism: pre-announce that you'll be market selling X amount of a given asset on an on-chain orderbook, in Y blocks 

Advantages: taps into latent OB liquidity, including AMM liquidity, effectively allowing retail to participate in liquidations

In my view of the future, the majority of trading activity and therefore price discovery moves on-chain. For this to happen, you need OBs/conc liquidity to allow traders to freely express preferences

The winning on-chain DEX then becomes the oracle, rather than relying on one
Oracle-based pricing a la GMX is a nice bootsrapping mechanism because it means you don't have to do your own price discovery, but it ensures you never become the primary trading venue

In this context, alongside other initiatives such as improved algorithms (e.g. Curve v2), slAMM becomes a way to further optimise returns for passive LPs across chains 

slAMM can be seen as a liquidity network dynamically reshuffling capital to wherever trading demand is highest

In my mind, DEXes will evolve to become settlement systems for range/limit orders. These will largely be dominated by advaned users / market-makers

In this world, AMMs become what their name implies, strategies for unsophisticated users to passively provide liquidity to DEXes

SLAMM explores a third way, using an app chain "hub" to coordinate liquidity between instances on different chains

This should mean better returns for LPs (deposit once, LP everywhere) and better execution for traders

2) deploy a unified app-chain on which all liquidity sits. This mitigates liquidity fragmentation but makes it difficult to compose synchronously with other dApps on native chains (e.g. @osmosiszone , @THORChain )

So far, most cross-chain AMMs have taken one of two approaches:

1) deploy standalone instances on different chains which don’t communicate, leading to liquidity fragmentation (e.g. @Uniswap , @SushiSwap )

Presenting slAMM: a potential design for a cross-chain AMM

They also have a fully built out DeFi ecosystem, including primitives that don't exist anywhere else like on-chain orderbooks (@ProjectSerum ), advanced structured products (@friktion_labs ), and integrated DeFi experiences (@mangomarkets )

Not only this, unlike EOS which never achieved meaningful traction outside low-effort gambling applications, Solana has built a real ecosystem

NFT volumes on Solana now account for a quarter of Eth, more than all other ecosystems put together https://t.co/DttfOL9SHC

However, in my experience interacting with the various ecosystems, I'd estimate Solana has a top 3 developer ecosystem (alongside Ethereum & Cosmos)

We realised we have a unique perspective on how we believe this should be built, the desire to bring it about, and, most importantly: the team to turn vision + desire into reality https://t.co/aTji2JwZah

After a lot of soul-searching, research, and strenuous internal debate, I’m happy to say we came out on the other side more bullish than ever on the future of crypto and DeFi + our ability to contribute to it

We didn’t just try and come up with answers that sound good. Delphi has no external investors and it’s our own founder capital that sustains Labs’s team of 50 

We wanted to make sure we’re brutally honest with ourselves and building towards a vision we all believe in

Does crypto matter? Why?
What is the future of crypto? What does the end-game UX look like? 
What ecosystem is best positioned to facilitate this?
What are the missing pieces to get to this end-game and how do we make it happen better and faster than it would without us?

While many wanted to move quickly, we knew we needed time to reflect, reassess and make sure we made the best long-term decision

@zmanian 👀

Curious what everyone's thoughts are on this framework? Is this how you see DeFi turning out? 

Is there anything I've missed or any ecosystems we should be looking at more closely?

Cosmos app-chains allow useful customisability as well as interoperability with other app-chains. However, they are relatively slow (~5 second block times) and have very little liquidity rn

Solana is fast but unstable. Chain halts are deadly here due to liquidations
Must bet on a particular L2 which, especially with ZK designs, involves high costs in terms of rewriting apps in diff programming languages

We're still doing a lot of research but as I see it rn, there's no obvious choice that satisfies these requirements 

L2s are fast but have no ecosystem and low interoperability.

Ecosystem - There needs to be enough of an ecosystem to enable many integrations with different projects and primitives (both DeFi and otherwise)

Ideally, the ecosystem should also attract new assets to launch there such that there's a constant flow of interesting new assets

Speed - While it'll never be as fast as a CEX, it should be as close as possible. Block times must be fast enough to ensure high leverage is possible (i.e. efficient oracle updates + liquidations)

Ideally it'd be also fast enough to enable an orderbook but this isn't mandatory

As I see it the two most important characteristics in selecting the right place to launch are:

1) Speed 
2) Ecosystem
Assuming we agree with this vision, where should something like this be built? Should it be its own app-chain, an L2 or should it launch on a generalised SC chain like Ethereum?
For instance, sufficiently liquid NFTs could eventually be integrated into the superdApp. Users would be able to leverage trade their favourite NFTs or use them to cross-collateralise other positions

Any contract that can be integrated into this superDapp, provided it is whitelisted by governance 

It will therefore be able tap into all the innovation that happens across DeFi and Web 3 more broadly
The decentralised Binance will be able to integrate and add leverage on top of any primitive that exists in DeFi, including stuff like LP'ing, options vaults, yield farms, etc
In addition to the obvious benefits such as being non-custodial and censorship-resistant, the primary advantage is interoperability

But what's the advantage of this vs just using a CEX? 

No matter how fast the chain, it will never be as fast as a CEX. As such, it will never be able to have a risk/liquidation engine that's as efficient, or offer as much leverage 

So why would users choose this over a CEX?

It's difficult (though not impossible) to achieve this by combining separate protocols because each of them have their own isolated risk parameters and liquidation logic 

The ideal is to design it this way intentionally from the beginning as one product

Rather than separate protocols, these should work as one experience, with users being able to combine different positions (spot, margin, perps, options, etc) into one "account" with a single liquidation threshold. 

Users could then have multiple sub-accounts, similar to CEXes

In my view this decentralised Binance 'superDapp' must include a few key elements: 

- Launchpad: Fair access to new projects via auction mechanisms
- Spot trading
- Lending & Borrowing
- Margin Trading 
- Derivs (mainly perps but eventually also options)
- Yield opportunities

I believe the future of DeFi is fully integrated experiences 

Users don't want to go one place to lend/borrow, another to trade spot, and yet another to trade perps

They want the Binance experience: one venue for all their DeFi needs

At Labs, we've been thinking a lot about the future of DeFi

While our thoughts on this are constantly evolving, wanted to share some of my current views on this to get some feedback from the community

I feel like we’ve mostly seen this play out as large CVX holders have been pretty value-add / long-term oriented participants in Curve governance

In general, I think synergistic protocols / DAOs are the best stakeholders for a project

However, Convex itself now has the locked price exposure and vlCVX holders should be incentivised to make good long-term decisions for Curve

Not just because it affects the value of their CVX but also the sustainability of the cvxCRV / CRV peg

The user of the liquid staking derivative still has price exposure since the price of the derivative will track underlying

What he has gained is liquidity on his previously locked position + yield, giving up his voting power in exchange

(4) A separate but related argument is that the Convex style liquid staking derivative ($cvxCRV) breaks the veToken incentive design by separating “voting power from price exposure” 

This isn’t the case

In the real world, bribing is simply called “lobbying” and it’s a multi-billion dollar industry

As I see it, bribing is simply creating a market for governance power, which should tend to make things more efficient

veToken holders can choose to be short-term oriented, but the locked capital forces them to bear the long-term drawbacks of bad governance

At a higher level, it seems to me people have a knee-jerk negative reaction to bribing which I’m not sure is warranted

Non-veTokens also make it much easier for style governance attacks such as the Justin Sun style borrowing tokens to sway a vote 

Governance takeovers also become harder as attacker by definition has the most long term skin in the game

https://t.co/vfwQXyLTgC

The 1st thing to point out is that bribing exists in any persmissionless system. Bribes are also possible with non-veTokens and it’s much easier to be short-term oriented here since you don’t have to live with the long-term consequences of your decisions

Since benefits of bribes are captured by the seller but the costs are socialised, this leads to sub-optimal outcomes where individuals are encouraged to maximise short-term profit at the expense of good, long-term governance decisions

(3) Bribes and short term thinking 

The argument is that veTokens don’t actually lead to long-term thinking due to the existence of bribes

Finally, even in the case of Convex, it’s a misnomer to call Curve ownership “centralised” just because Convex owns 50% of governance power 

After all, this is distributed amongst CVX holders. This is even more so the case with the introduction of fractional governance

My base case is that there will be multiple Convex-style protocols built on Astroport, each w/ their own liquid staking derivative, creating a healthy competitive market

We're already seeing this with @retrogrademoney,@reactor_money,@ApolloDAO, all entering the $ASTRO wars

Instead of a whitelist, Astroport allows all pools to have a gauge (i.e. to be be eligible to be voted on to receive emissions), with only the top 10 (parameter set by governance) receiving issuance pro rata to their share of votes

We don’t believe this centralisation would’ve happened if Curve were more open with its whitelisting process from the beginning 

Alternatively, it’s also possible to remove the whitelist altogether which is what @astroport_fi has chosen to do

While this did happen with Convex, we don’t believe this is due to any inherent network effects but rather because of the Curve whitelist which allowed Convex to gain a massive head start competitive advantage

https://t.co/48k40bEDpJ

(2) The argument here is that vetokens naturally lead to centralisation of governance power due to higher barriers to participation + network effects of liquid staking derivs 

The example cited is @ConvexFinance which now controls 50% of Curve governance power

The “governance takeover” framing is also strange since those conducting the “takeover” would have the most skin in the game and incentive to ensure the changes made are positive

Once again, seems like a feature to me rather than a bug

The argument that “governance security will fall for multi year periods during ownership transitions (when large holders stop relocking tokens in preparation for sale” also makes little sense to me since it assumes there will be no other governance participants coming in

There’s nothing inherent in the veModel that makes it more appealing to whales. In fact it’s the only token model where a smaller, more long-term oriented holder can magnify their governance power vs a less committed whale
In my view, it’s better for a community to have a smaller number of highly motivated, long-term oriented governors than a large number of passive, disinterested ones

The whole point of the veToken is to dilute governance power away from short-term motivated participants and towards long-term oriented participants. There are naturally less of the latter than the former

This is a feature, not a bug.

In a similar vein, it is argued that this makes governance attacks easier by “raising cost to defend against takeovers”

This argument makes very little sense to me

(2) Reduces investor base / makes governance attacks easier 

The argument here is that not many people are willing to lock for multiple years and that veTokens thus reduce potential investor/governor base

I believe their arguments can be grouped into 4 main reasons why veTokens are bad:



(1) Reduce investor base  
(2) Centralise governance power 
(3) Lead to bribes and short term thinking
(4) Liquid staking deriv breaks token incentive design

Will address each of them in turn

19/ Unlike in the traditional world where users can only have one identity, the web 3 paradigm will enable users to have multiple identities ('alts')

18/ Your Delphi subscription, your privacy preferences, your follower count, your valid KYC certificate. All these things could be attached to an Avatar within a wallet

9/ Avatar Protocol is a way to combine these disparate ideas into a cohesive identity

The first use case is composable pfps, editing your pfp video game style

7/ It's easy to focus on this, extrapolate from the past, and assume that LUNA is doomed to the same fate as its predecessors. But as with all venture investing, the right question to ask is "What if it works?"

6/ It's important to recognise that, other than $UST which hasn't just survived but thrived, all other algorithmic stablecoin systems have fallen victim to the death spiral 

As someone who still holds a decent amount of $ESD, I can tell you a death spiral is no fun at all

5/ The risk is the so-called death spiral, depicted below

Endogenous collateral creates reflexivity which just means a self-reinforcing positive loop; $UST contraction leads to $LUNA being minted and declining in price, which leads to fear and more $UST redemptions https://t.co/vrWcV7VnKJ

4/ Algo stables don't require debt or external collateral. As a result, they're more capital efficient and can grow far quicker than their debt-based counterparts

However, this also means they have higher tail risk and are less resilient to black swan type events

This is in contrast to debt-based stablecoins such as @MakerDAO which are overcollateralised by external assets

Disclaimer: Delphi is an investor and advisor to Everlend. We're also long $SOL

If this sounds interesting, recommend you join Everlend's Discord and try out the Alpha

Note: Currently only works for the deposit side, with borrowing coming live in Q2

Litepaper with more deets here: https://t.co/UtN2RVU6CR

https://t.co/hPCN36fFf8

While it sounds simple in a tweet thread, this is actually a very hard problem to solve, especially in a fully decentralised and trustless way

It's also a massive opportunity as eventually, if Everlend succeeds, we expect most users to lend and borrow through them

Think cross-margin where a user can effectively have collateral on one MM but borrow from another

Both the calculations to determine the correct distribution of collateral and the constant rebalancing/refinancing operations would be prohibitively expensive to do on Eth

The borrow side is where the magic happens 

Everlend uses a "liquidity oracle" and sub-wallet architecture to: a) calculate the optimal collateral distribution and b) dynamically shift around collateral and refinance a user's loans to minimise borrow costs https://t.co/rfo1mgLYD6

Everlend is a money market aggregator or "meta bank", optimising yield for depositors and borrow cost for borrowers

On the deposit side, it looks a lot like @iearnfinance's initial "earn" product, constantly moving deposits between different MMs to get the best yield https://t.co/PaOvvTW3lw

Love the @arca team but I voted no on proposal 18 

Can be easily sybiled (just creates additional complexity for whales) and imo not a good use of @anchor_protocol dev resources

https://t.co/chmVJXjAFa
Accumulators accumulate

🔹DAOs like @retrogrademoney would still look to accumulate $ANC in order to maximise earn rate for users and minimize borrow costs for borrowers
🔹Doesn’t dictate whether incentives should go to earn or borrow side but instead allows governors to decide based on what's needed

🔹Preserves simplicity as earn depositors still earn 20% and don’t need to interact with veANC if they don’t want to
🔹Allows boosted rewards for depositors that have skin in the game, achieving the incentive alignment objectives highlighted by @josh_rosenthal/@Matt_Hepler

veANC holders could then also apply boosties to their earn or borrow positions, increasing their share of $ANC rewards received 

This has a few key advantages: 

🔹Preserves $aUST composability since yield would be paid in ANC on top of base earn rate

Instead of choosing between borrow side and earn side incentives, why not have both and let the governors decide? 

The simple design would be to have gauges for aUST as well as all collateral assets, allowing veANC holders to vote on where they think ANC incentives should go

@retrogrademoney's proposal preferred borrow-side incentives whereas @arca / @polychaincap's proposal and @pedroexplore1's proposal prioritise earn-side incentives (albeit with different implementations)

Why not both? https://t.co/81d4J4kRSf

Firstly, I'm a fan of veTokens and I think veANC, while not a panacea, is still an improvement on the current token econ

My sense is that most people agree that with this, and most of the debate is about whether to provide veANC “boosties” on the borrow side or the earn side

I've been incredibly impressed with the quality of discourse around the @anchor_protocol veANC proposal

6. NFT Fractionalisation (i.e. @fractional_art) 

Fractionalising NFTs into fungible CW20s. This would democratise access to high-value NFTs (e.g. super rare GPs) by allowing anyone to gain exposure by buying fractions of an NFT or portfolio of NFTs

5. Prediction markets 

Prediction markets are one of the OG blockchain use cases. While we're skeptical of the peer-to-peer model, we'd love to see someone build a peer-to-pool betting protocol focused around a specific niche (i.e. Synthetix for betting)

This could also include features like: 
- batch buying/selling for time and gas efficiency 
- optimal routing for users who simply want to "sweep the floor" on a given collection
- batch listing, allowing sellers to list across all marketplaces
Instead, it'd be ideal if there was a platform that aggregated all existing marketplaces and allowed users to easily browse and buy NFTs from their favourite collections across all of them
While competition is great, it does make UX challenging as users must browse through each one to find what they want

4. NFT Aggregator (i.e. @geniexyz on Terra)

Terra's NFT scene is thriving with multiple NFT marketplaces including @randomearth_io , @knowhere_art , @protocoltalis and many others

3. Off-chain voting (i.e. @SnapshotLabs on Terra)

Off-chain governance (similar to @SnapshotLabs) would use digital signatures to verify voting results without requiring participants to spend gas on transactions, reducing friction for gov participation

This is an end-game crypto product experience, allowing users to have access to CEX like cross-margin experiences with the added benefit of incorporating farming strategies

With @mars_protocol SC credit lines, both collateral and debt sit in SCs and can be liquidated. The assets borrowed must be held in the SC so they can be liquidated and/or can only interact with whitelisted SCs

This allows for much higher leverage and capital efficiency

In traditional money market protocols, only the users' collateral sits in smart contracts (SCs) and can be liquidated. The assets borrowed are held by the user and can be taken wherever they want 

As a result, users can only borrow less than what they put in as collateral

Anchor achieves its fixed rate by leveraging the most stable yield in crypto: PoS asset staking yield

This makes it less dependent on borrowing / utilisation since it can use the PoS validator rewards to guarantee a yield for depositors

Anchor is a savings-as-a-service protocol. Its goal is to provide a fixed APR that depositors can rely on

Mars is a decentralised credit protocol. Its goal is to become the credit facility for dApps and SCs

Anchor targets consumers. Mars serves (mainly) protocols

This effectively allows Astroport to treat aUST and UST as the same asset, enabling users to denominate in whatever they want while ensuring the liquidity sitting in pools is productive 

This architecture could be used cross-chain provided DEXes implemented this virtual pool

Buying ANC w/ UST - Astroport routes the UST through the UST / aUST pool first (ie deposits UST in Anchor), then uses the aUST to buy ANC

Selling ANC for UST - Astroport sells ANC for aUST, then routes aUST through aUST / UST pool (ie withdraws UST from Anchor)

This achieves the best of both worlds since Astroport liquidity can sit on Anchor, but users can still trade and interact with it via UST with zero slippage or fees

To make this clearer, let's go through an example with a hypothetical $aUST / $ANC pool

An alternative solution is to implement a "virtual pool" (h/t @LidoFinance for the idea)

This would not be a normal pool in that users cannot add liquidity to it. Instead, all it would do is deposit / withdraw UST / aUST from Anchor

All credit goes to the Delphi Labs risk team, specifically @ayana_eltai and @JonathanErlichL who crushed this research

A special thank you to @euler_mab, @Mudit__Gupta, and many others who provided feedback and helped refine our thinking on this

We analyse the costs of various attacks and use this to derive optimal TWAP parameters 

This research has informed design choices on @mars_protocol TWAPs. We hope it can also be useful for others in the space

If you want to talk about this, our DMs are always open

While there are various kinds of oracle solutions, for this article we focus primarily on the on-chain TWAP oracle initially pioneered by @Uniswap and used by @astroport_fi 

This will also be the primary oracle used by @mars_protocol's Fields of Mars

In (1) the goal is to pump the price of a collateral asset, enabling the attacker to borrow > than the collateral's real value 

In (2) the goal is to dump the price of a collateral / pump the price of a debt asset to 'falsely' liquidate another user (i.e. buy collateral cheaply)

At the highest level, money market oracle manipulation attacks can be broken down into two main categories:

(1) False collateral value increase

17/ However, if the value of $ASTRO drops to $0.35 the user now has only 259.8 UST and 845.15 ASTRO for a total of $591.61

16/ Let’s put some numbers on it to see how it works

An entrepreneur uses 500ASTRO worth $1 each to borrow $500UST. His collateral is $1000 of ASTRO-UST LP shares and he owes $5000 UST. 

His LTV is 0.5 and the SC enforces a margin requirement of 0.83

15/ The entrepreneur is now levered 2x long, earning 2x the yield. But isn't this risky for the lender?

No, because the SC holds the LP shares as collateral and enforces a certain margin requirement. If this level is reached, anyone can call a function which does the following: https://t.co/Ea08GEmvbx
15/ Instead, the entrepreneur can apply for a credit line from the Red Bank. In order to do so, he writes a smart contract which does the following: https://t.co/QrFPJgIq3y

14/ A traditional money market wouldn’t help since he can only borrow less than what he puts in

A traditional lender would never lend to a farmer, but if they did they’d require a business plan, KYC and a high interest rate to compensate for the tx costs and risk of default

13/ In this case, the entrepreneur is the farmer. He’s bullish ASTRO and wants to accumulate as much of it as possible through farming the ASTRO/UST pool

 Normally, he’d be limited by the amount of spot ASTRO and UST he holds

12/ To make this less abstract, let’s look at an example of it in action such as the Leveraged Yield Farming (LYF) initially pioneered by @AlphaFinanceLab

LYF is an example of SC lending https://t.co/gFTOdPAoJ0

11/ Crucially, the loan is trustless in that the lender doesn’t need to know anything about the borrower in order to make a decision (no more credit history), nor do they need to rely on the legal system to make sure they get paid in case of default

9/ In crypto, SCs can hold tokenised collateral representing a borrower’s assets. As long as the tokens are liquid and the SC & game theory function as designed, the lender can underwrite knowing a defaulting borrower will be liquidated as soon as his margin threshold is breached

8/ Tokenised collateral IRL, borrowers may hold all sorts of https://t.co/WImtk7jzii order to liquidate, lenders must go through expensive and time-consuming legal processes with no guarantee of getting their money back (e.g. borrower flees the country or declares bankruptcy)
7/ In crypto, lenders can lend to SCs where they only need to examine the code to figure out what it’s doing and whether they’re willing to underwrite the risks

6/ SC lending 

In the real world, lenders lend to counterparties and must trust them to use the money the way they said they would 

As a result, in TradFi much more time (and money) must be spent establishing trust

5/ Crypto replaces legal enforcement with systems of incentives. This  reduces the cost of enforcement and thus eliminates the need to establish trust 

There are two elements which combine to make crypto lending different: 

(1) Smart contract lending
(2) Tokenised collateral

As a result, much more time (and money) must be spent establishing trust in counterparties via cumbersome KYC, credit & background checks, business plan assessment, etc 

High cost of enforcement → high cost of establishing trust → higher interest rates
5/ Enforcement in TradFi is notoriously expensive, with liquidation involving messy, time-consuming legal processes.
4/ Therefore, debt is nothing but a legally enforceable promise. It cannot exist without legal agreement and cannot be enforced without courts of law

3/ In TradFi, debt is a legal construct 

Specifically, lenders lend money to borrowers who promise to pay back principal + interest over some time period

If they fail to do so, the lender has legally protected rights to enforcement

2/ Rather than porting concepts directly from TradFi, we believe in using crypto’s inherent advantages to create new, better primitives

In order to understand these advantages, we must first examine how credit works in TradFi and how this differs from crypto

1/ Many say DeFi is inefficient because all lending must be overcollateralised – you have to lock up more than what you borrow

They then argue the solution is moving to some form of trust-based "uncollateralised" lending

We agree with the problem, but not with the solution

Mars isn't just another money market 

It’s a generalised credit protocol enabling both peer-to-smart contract AND smart contract-to-smart contract lending 🔴

The latter is the real breakthrough and what I’m most excited about.

9/ It also means bettors benefit from: 

🔹familiar UX with well-specified bets (including multiple outcomes & accumulators) 
🔹accurate pricing pulled in from casinos & sportsbooks
🔹very strong liquidity & depth across markets

8/ This design means LPs don't have to manually create markets nor are they exposed to market-specific risk

Instead, they can passively provide liquidity and collect fees similar to what they would do in other DeFi apps

7/ How does Azuro tackle the liquidity fragmentation issues outlined above? 

a) Uses a single pool of liquidity that collateralises all markets  

b) Focusing on a single niche (sportsbetting) and pulls in prices using an oracle

6/ I put out a tweet a few months ago outlining a high-level design for a prediction market I believed could address these issues 

Since then, I spoke to many teams in this space but none impressed me as much as @azuroprotocol 

https://t.co/shHHyjMtvD

5/ In terms of product focus, existing PMs have also fragmented liquidity by going too broad 

Users can create markets for almost anything, splitting attention and leading to so-called "Design Flaw attacks" (see section 3 "A Controversial Market")

https://t.co/twqTdlyKJy

4/ P2P architectures also have other flaws such as being inefficient for bets with more than two outcomes, not allowing accumulator style bets, poor UX (e.g. "invalid" settlements due to mis-specified bets), among many others

3/ This means users' ability to bet on one side of a market is constrained by liquidity on the other side of that market 

This has led to low liquidity, terrible odds and hardly any bet volume https://t.co/UBDaXvdAzt

2/ In terms of mech design, most PMs have used P2P architectures

In these designs, not only do LPs have to bootstrap each individual betting market but also the "yes" and "no" side of each market, effectively setting the odds and taking all the betting risk related to that mkt

Prediction markets are one of the OG crypto use cases that most excite people's imagination 

And yet all attempts at building them so far have failed

13/ After all, there are many things that don’t generate cashflows but are nonetheless valuable to govern because they affect the cashflows of underlying projects that benefit from or leverage the public good in some way

All this could be funded through @angelprotocol https://t.co/YLwawmOFIM

9/ How big is this market? I believe it’s much bigger than most people assume

8/ While voes are non-binding, over time we believe charities that involve the community will attract more stakers and outperform their less decentralised counterparts

CS holders will also be able to participate in protocol-level governance based on the $HALO price of their CS https://t.co/L2i5H8A9sC

7/ Stakers benefit the platform in 3 ways: 

🔹Curation - the amount of $HALO staked on a charity determines its visibility on the platform
🔹Insurance - stakers will be slashed in case of charity misbehaviour
🔹Governance - stakers participate in charity governance decisions

6/ Good stakers may return multiples while bad ones could theoretically even face negative returns; a true “work token”

But why should stakers get paid in the 1st place? What service are they providing?
5/ This means that rather than a uniform staking yield as with most other protocols, @angelprotocol stakers will receive a variable yield based on the performance of the charities they stake into

4/ Users stake $HALO to charities of their choice, receiving back charity shares (CS) minted on a bonding curve 

A % of the charity's future donations are used to buy HALO and deposit it into the bonding curve, creating a link btwn charity performance and CS price https://t.co/4GAqacjNCt

3/ Rather than a centralised, top-down charity vetting process, we instead tried to create a bottom-up, decentralised mechanism using what we're calling a bonding curve token curated registry 

While this sounds complicated, it really isn’t

2/ To succeed, Angel needs to attract quality charities that people want to donate to

How can the protocol ensure this is the case without deferring to centralised gatekeepers?

This is where the $HALO token economic design comes in

Social consensus to instantly blacklist liquid staking derivative solutions that do this 

Remove ability for EOAs to participate in locking

26/ There have been a lot of questions from the community about the Astrodrop launch mechanics. 

With this in mind, @yandelphi and I will be jumping on a Twitter spaces on 4/11 to do a short presentation + Q&A for the community

Join us here: https://t.co/xdYXSNfIW1

25/ There are a lot of other dope features about Astroport, such as TWAP price oracles which will be used by @mars_protocol, dual LP incentives, improved UX (thx to the @ideocolab ninjas) and much more 

Read the litepaper for more info: https://t.co/Yfi6LbRRor

24/ In the spirit of community participation, Astroport will be launching with an innovative lockdrop + liquidity bootstrap auction architecture, distributing 7.5% of its supply to committed LPs 

Read more about this here: https://t.co/lHiBW3i3vh

23/ Our hope is that this token economic design encourages a diverse community of users, projects, and other ecosystem participants to stake and contribute to the DAO

We believe this level of community involvement will ultimately result in a better protocol

22/ Crucially Astroport has no VCs or passive investors 

Instead, it has been bootstrapped by the contributors who built it, including Terraform Labs, @Delphi_Digital, @IDEOVC , @atticlab_it, @stablekwon, @Lomashuk from @LidoFinance, @madcapslaugh, and many others

21/ Perhaps most importantly, @astroport_fi will be community-owned, with 70% of supply accruing to the community

30% will belong to the initial contributors to the Astroport JV who will be vested over 3 years https://t.co/f4CzTvUng7

20/ Share of protocol fees

Stakers will receive a share of protocol fees

Half of these fees are used to buy back $ASTRO and stake it into $xASTRO, accruing to all assemblers. The other half is distributed to vxAstro stakers to reward those with more skin in the game https://t.co/Qrp8qnDWMB

19/ Preferential yield 

LPs who are also stakers will receive a boost to their share of ASTRO emissions. This creates a virtuous circle in which LPs are encouraged to become assemblers and vice versa

18/ This mechanism means all stakeholders (LPs, community members and even projects themselves) are incentivised to participate in governance in order to maximise the governance power they earn from their preferred pools https://t.co/VPQjzpEkvY

17/ This will take the form of a bi-weekly governance game where assemblers vote for their favourite pools with the top 8 receiving incentives proportional to the votes they received https://t.co/GCNMQkbei0

16/ Direct the flow of Astro 

55% of $ASTRO supply is earmarked to be distributed to LPs over 4 years

Assemblers get to decide which pools receive $ASTRO incentives and how much each pool receives

15/ In exchange for governing the protocol, Assemblers will receive a set of key benefits: 

 ✦ Direct the flow of $ASTRO via voting
 ✦ Preferential yield (boosties)
 ✦ A share of protocol fees https://t.co/r2hBs8JGpZ

14/ Assemblers will be able to multiply their influence by demonstrating skin in the game, locking their $xASTRO for up to 2 years and receiving additional vxASTRO points 

This provides a mechanism for high-conviction smaller holders to magnify their influence and rewards

13/ Astroport will be fully governed by the Astral Assembly: Astroport’s DAO which will is responsible for all protocol decisions

Any $ASTRO holder can participate in the assembly by staking $ASTRO, receiving back $xASTRO

12/ Token Econ & Governance 

Astroport is a public good for the Terra ecosystem. To fulfil its role, it must be owned and governed by its users 

Astroport’s $ASTRO token acts as a key coordination mechanism, combining best practices learned from other protocols https://t.co/8dXQCKopJ6

11/ LBPs, pioneered by @BalancerLabs, are a token launch mechanism that enables price discovery while preventing the bot frontrunning that affects other launch mechanisms 

They’ve become extremely popular on Ethereum and I expect the same to happen on Terra

10/ Astroport’s invariant pools will allow Orion to do the swapping on the Terra side instead, saving on fees (see diagram below)

Another example of where invariant pools can be useful is the $bLUNA - $LUNA pool, leading to far more efficient liquidity around the $LUNA price https://t.co/JuNfpRvcNz

9/ As a practical example, consider the following: 

@Orion_money lets users swap from any stablecoin on Ethereum to $UST, bridging it to Terra and depositing into Anchor. It currently uses @CurveFinance for swaps and its users must therefore pay high Ethereum gas fees

8/ Stableswap invariant pools allow for efficient trading between stable assets such as stablecoins or different wrapped versions of the same assets (e.g. $bLUNA / $LUNA)

These will become increasingly important as the Terra ecosystem grows and connects to other chains

7/ @terraswap_io currently only supports xy=k pools 

In addition to these, Astroport will also initially support Stableswap Invariant pools as well as Liquidity Bootstrapping Pools (LBPs) https://t.co/vxMVJMVyak
6/ It then routes among these different pools to ensure optimal execution for traders, basically functioning as its own aggregator

5/ Astroport takes a different approach 

Instead of specialising in a particular algorithm, it uses a flexible architecture that allows builders to create new pool types that fit seamlessly within Astroport with minimal changes to core protocol code
4/ It also means traders must use "aggregators" such as @1inch which route across these AMMs to ensure optimal execution, introducing a secondary layer of fees

3/ On Ethereum, most AMMs have elected to specialise in a particular pool type 

This means LPs must understand and select between a variety of AMMs to find the optimal one for their assets and preferences

2/ Flexible pool model 

Different AMMs use different algorithms (also referred to as "pool types") to price assets, with each one being appropriate for certain kinds of assets

For instance, Uniswap's xyk pool is appropriate for volatile assets but inefficient for stable assets

1/ As I see it, @astroport_fi provides two fundamental improvements to existing AMMs: 

 ✦ Flexible pool model
 ✦ Token econ & governance 

I'll cover each of them in turn https://t.co/JHvVx4ixyI

22/ At this point, $UST will offer:

- a next-gen, non-custodial financial system complete with all major primitives and a wide variety of assets
- real world payment utility across multiple geographies

All while being decentralised and censorship-resistant

21/ In parallel, neobanks like @alice_finance, @kado_money ,@kashdefi ,@SuberraProtocol and others will continue to grow and unlock $UST payments utility across the globe

This helps to close the loop while also introducing a non-cyclical source of $UST demand
19/ @mirror_protocol will continues to port over the highest demand synthetic assets from the real world, including pre and post-IPO stocks, commodities and bonds

18/ A financial system is nothing without assets people want

@wormholecrypto, and later IBC, will enable Terra to import the most sought after assets from other chains. It will also enable Terra assets to be exported to other chains, starting with @solana and @ethereum

17/ Gradually then suddenly, Terra will have created a complete DeFi ecosystem, including strong primitives for synthetic assets, exchange, leveraged farming / trading, and asset management

All with an actual decentralised stablecoin at the heart of it

15/ Then, taking advantage of the variety of financial primitives and assets on Terra, @spar_protocol will launch, empowering asset managers to create on-chain, non-custodial funds

Arbitrage funds, yield farming funds, long-short hedge funds, etc can all be created on Spar
14/ As $UST establishes itself as the dominant decentralised stablecoin, @Levana_protocol's UST backed leveraged assets will become prime cross-chain collateral

13/ Next, @levana_protocol will come to market offering leveraged exposure to any Terra asset, first using leveraged tokens (via @mars_protocol) and later through decentralised perps

7/ Just as Orion sucks cryptodollars ($USDT/$USDC) into $UST, @anchor_protocol's 20% savings rate will continue to absorb real world dollars into $UST through integrations with wallets and fintech apps

5/ The ultimate goal is “closing the loop” such that a user never has to leave $UST. This requires highly developed investment and spending ecosystems

The next few months leading up to and following Columbus 5 will unleash massive progress in both of these areas

4/ 

Investment - TeFi gives users access to a full decentralised financial system (yield, lending, synthetics, asset mgmt, exchange) + wide range of assets to invest in

Spending - Initially Chai and increasingly others are helping to make $UST spendable worldwide

3/ The decentralisation mechanisms are well-covered, so I’ll focus mostly on utility. What makes money useful? 

Money can either be spent or held/invested (deferred spending) 

Terra aims to make $UST useful for both

1/ Before we begin, it’s important to realise what Terra is

Terra’s product is often misunderstood as an L1 

In reality, Terra’s only product is $UST. Everything else, including the L1, simply exists to help make $UST the most useful and decentralised form of money there is

Few realise it, but #TerraAutumn is coming 🌖🍂

5/ We think crypto's true innovation lies in decentralisation: using incentive design to encourage disparate, self-interested actors to cooperate in ways that recreate and improve on services currently provided by trusted intermediaries

18/ Another challenge will be building sufficient liquidity in the LTAs

After all, lenders know they are lending to short-sellers which may make this an unattractive proposition for them, especially since LTAs often have high yields available for staking/LPing anyway

17/ With LTA loans the protocol's losses are potentially unlimited 

Once outstanding loan > collateral + liquidation fee, there is no incentive for liquidators to liquidate but the LTA may continue to pump 

Bad loans --> shortfall events --> potential protocol insolvency

16/ To be clear, there are still risks to this model 

Even as pure borrow assets, LTA's high volatility and low liquidity means that loans may be difficult to liquidate during extreme market moves

15/ The advantage of this architecture is that it preserves the advantages of a single pool model wrt not fragmenting liquidity

At the same time, it minimizes the risks of LTAs by making them unusable as collateral

14/ Traders deposit collateral assets and borrow LTAs against them to short, paying an interest rate to LTA lenders

Lenders deposit LTAs which are loaned to traders, collecting a yield in return

13/ @beta_finance uses a single pool model but one specialised for short-selling LTAs

Basically, there are two types of assets:  

- collateral assets which can only be used as collateral
- borrow assets (LTAs) which can be loaned/borrowed but cannot be used as collateral

12/ The data seems to bear this out as thus far isolated pool lending protocols have failed to achieve meaningful traction compared to single pool designs

So, how does @beta_finance's design allow for borrowing of LTAs?

11/ Users must determine for each pool whether the yield adequately compensates them for the risks they're taking on

In my view, this defeats the main value of a money market for most users: earning interest on idle assets with minimal effort and risk

10/ A user on @AaveAave can simply deposit USDC and earn interest on it, knowing they're protected by the Safety Module in case of a Shortfall Event

On Fuse / Kashi, there are multiple USDC pools, each offering different yields and posing different risks

9/ One way to look at this is that the single pool design offloads risk decisions (and potential downside of these decisions) to a DAO whereas segregated pool relies on individual users making the decisions and taking the downside

8/ In both these architectures, shortfall events only affect lenders in the specific pool where they happen rather than the entire protocol 

The tradeoff is that liquidity is fragmented and risk decisions must be made by individual lenders rather than the protocol

7/ In the case of Rari, the idea is that eventually anyone will be able to create their own money market pool of collateral and borrow assets, defining their risk parameters and oracles

In the case of Kashi, risks are isolated within each individual collateral/borrow pair

6/ The common thread between all these issues is that cross-margin protocols are only as strong as their weakest collateral asset

Permissionless architectures like @RariCapital's fuse pools or @SushiSwap's Kashi address this by segregating assets and therefore risks

5/ More straight forwardly, liquidity for an LTA may simply dry up during an extreme market move, meaning liquidators are not willing to take on the risk of selling the collateral

This leads to a shortfall event which can cause potential protocol insolvency

4/ Alternatively, assuming an SC "infinite mint" exploit, an attacker can simply keep minting more tokens and depositing them as collateral on the lending protocol, borrowing external assets as the oracle fails to update

3/ If they're accepted as collateral, LTAs (i.e. shitcoins) can be used to borrow quality assets. This is problematic

For example, if an LTA oracle is manipulated and the price is set to infinity, an attacker can potentially borrow all the other assets on the lending protocol

2/ The reason LTAs aren't listed on protocols like @AaveAave / @compoundfinance is because, due to these protocol's cross-margin based architecture, every new asset introduces systemic risk

This is especially the case when they can be used as collateral

1/ Long tail assets (LTAs) are characterized by relatively high volatility, low liquidity as well as potentially high smart contract and counterparty risks

The appeal of shorting LTAs is clear, so why isn't this possible at scale on existing lending protocols?

18/ As always, time will tell whether or not we made the right call

The beautiful thing about having skin in the game is that we will bear the consequences either way, both reputational and financial

17/ Bearish takes are always tough in crypto, especially ones that piss off some of crypto’s strongest communities 

Nevertheless, I’m proud of the research team for staying true to what they believe in

16/ For better or for worse, we're not short term traders looking to time market cycles

We research, invest in, and contribute to the projects we believe will make up the futur of france. We intend to HODL for the years it takes this future to play out

15/ What I can say with certainty is that we will always put out the research we believe to be true, regardless of the consequences

We're playing long-term games here. We've built not just our brand but also our fund on the quality of our research

14/ As with everything at Delphi, it starts with research. We chose to position ourselves after doing the research, not vice versa. Research reports present our views which are reflected in our portfolio

To be clear, we could be wrong! It’s happened before and will happen again

13/ In recent reports, many were quick to point out that we owned positions in some of the assets covered but not others

This is important context (which is why we disclose it upfront) but to say this makes our report biased is to invert cause and effect

12/ We got a lot of hate for our bearish $NFTX take in Feb, where we pointed out the problems we saw with the design (ht @CoalieBee). The asset is down >90% since

In general our bearish takes have significantly underperformed the market

11/ This is also why we've never shied away from being critical. In crypto, no one gets any love for bearish takes but not losing money is as important as making money 

While we're all crypto permabulls, it's important to be able to separate the wheat from the chaff

10/ We also have reputational skin in the game

Analyst's real world identities and most importantly, @Delphi_Digital 's brand, are both attached to every report we write

This brand has been painstakingly built over years of quality research. It's our most valuable asset

9/ I believe the quality of our research would be significantly, if not fatally, impaired if the team couldn't own assets covered

All my favourite Delphi reports covered assets which the fund or team members held positions in ($BTC Jan '19, $SNX Aug '19, $RUNE Dec '19, etc)

7/ I also care about transparency and whether the researcher owns the asset being discussed or competitors

But this is purely to make sure their portfolio matches their stated views (i.e. verify their skin in the game)

6/ The only independence I truly care about in the context of investment research is whether the person has been paid to write the report

This is a clear conflict of interest and would cause me to take the report with a heavy grain of salt

5/ So what about “independence” ?

Complete independence would require not owning any crypto. While I know some in the space do this, I would personally heavily discount investment research written by someone without skin in the game

4/ This applies IRL too

Before taking advice from someone on anything from health to shitcoins, you'd want to know: 1) whether they've tried it themselves 2) what qualifies them to give this advice

Both of these are tests of skin in the game

3/ It’s no coincidence that the most impactful research I’ve read in crypto has been written by non-anons with high reputational and financial skin in the game

Whether it’s @Arthur_0x's original $SNX thesis, @multicoincap's $SOL report or @Delphi_Digital's $RUNE report

2/ This is especially the case when combined with 1) a reputation and 2) a RL identity attached to this reputation 

While I love anons (we’ve both hired and invested in a few), identity clearly implies higher skin in the game because unlike an alias it’s not discardable

1/ In crypto most assets are liquid. As a result, what someone owns (or doesn’t own) should be a pretty accurate representation of their views 

“Don’t ask someone what they think, ask them what’s in their portfolio” - @nntaleb

The nature of crypto means everyone is always talking their book

You can see this negatively as bias or positively as skin in the game. In my view, as long as there's transparency, this is actually a massive net positive

Ultimately, the traditional cross-collateral model offloads risk decisions (and potential downside of these decisions) to a DAO whereas isolated pool relies on individual users making the decisions and taking the downside

While isolated pool models offer higher returns, users have to regularly shift their assets around pools to maximize yield

They also have to determine for each pool whether the yield adequately compensates them for the risks they're taking on

The appeal of money markets for most users is earning interest on idle assets with minimal effort and risk 

E.g. on @AaveAave, users can just deposit their USDC and earn interest on it, knowing they're protected by the Safety Module in case of a Shortfall Event

Early days, but so far isolated pool money market (MM) designs such as @RariCapital's Fuse and @SushiSwap's kashi seem to have very little adoption, with $34m and <10m in TVL respectively

At this point, a bear market is just a bull market in stablecoins (ht @samkazemian); counter-cylicality is achieved

9/ Most algo stables try and address the death spiral via mechanism design, creating incentives for long-term believers to come in and stabilize the system by buying coupons/bonds

These attempts have thus far all failed

8/ To understand how Terra achieved this we have to understand how algo stables work

An algo stable is inherently capital efficient since no external collateral is required. The tradeoff is higher blow-up risk via reflexivity on the downside: the so-called “death spiral” https://t.co/FcUVuXcggq

7/ $UST is the only decentralised stablecoin which has managed to maintain its peg while not being backed by centralised collateral

It has done this by building actual demand for its stablecoin, initially via Chai and recently via TeFi

@makerDAO’s $DAI is currently backed ~40% by USDC and are looking to increase this further https://t.co/oeWyn9Zqof

4/ The march of regulation is one-way

It’s clear to me that centralised stablecoins will increasingly become more regulated and restricted. As they do, they will push the crypto industry towards decentralised stablecoins 

This is one of the largest TAMs in crypto

3/ This is not just academic. Circle has already blacklisted multiple USDC wallets 

Any protocol which relies on USDC as part of LPs or as collateral inherits its vulnerabilities. The consequences of blacklisting would be potential protocol insolvency 

https://t.co/PdF4HRlwxg

2/ Centralised stablecoins are IOUs for dollars held in a bank account attached to a legal entity

Not only do users face counterparty risk with issuers, they also face potential censorship by nation states as legal entities can be coerced and bank accs frozen

1/ Stablecoins have become the backbone of DeFi, with nearly $100b in cumulative market cap

I love SF but will high earners continue to pay a ~40% tax rate for the privilege of living in a busy, expensive, dangerous city if they don't have to?

Others will take advantage by being more efficient and providing better services at more reasonable prices

High value citizens will flow from the former to the latter

In a remote working world, citizens of overpriced states will also become less competitive in the labour force due to high fixed costs (rent, cost of living taxes)

With remote working, why would you hire someone in NYC/SF if you can hire the same level of talent elsewhere?

With the move to remote work and digital value, citizen switching costs go down dramatically 

Capital and labour become far more mobile. States which don’t provide enough value for the price they charge (taxes) will see their citizens go elsewhere

Nation states provide a service to citizens

Until now, low capital and labour mobility made each nation state a monopoly since citizens couldn’t leave without significant friction

As monopolies, they could afford to be expensive and inefficient

17/ Different combinations of tokenized perps and farming strategies will be composed and packaged into strategies by @yearn_fi and perhaps even asset managers on @enzyme_ , @dHedgeOrg  and others

All this gets put on steroids with the upcoming Alpha X: Alpha’s tokenised perps product

15/ V2 also allows for more degen farming strats as users can get levered yield while being long their favourite coins vs USD rather than ETH. Think farming Pool 2s on 2x notional

Exposures also become easier to manage as farmers are no longer farming with two volatile assets

14/ On Alpha V1, all strategies were short ETH

With Alpha V2 adding stablecoin pools, farmers will be able to borrow stables and get yield-bearing long exposure to their favourite assets

Instead of paying funding on perps, users will get paid to be long on Alpha V2

13/ V2 advances Alpha towards becoming the go-to industrial yield farming platform 

While a lot of the features like new kinds of collateral and more pools on @CurveFinance are dope, the one I'm personally most excited about is stablecoin lending pools

12/ It’s not just degen yield though, leverage also gives farmers greater flexibility 

You might want to farm the Pool 2 ETH pair on your favourite asset, but for some reason you’re bearish ETH and don’t want the exposure (ngmi)

On Alpha, you can borrow the $ETH and farm

11/ On @AlphaFinanceLab, both your collateral and your debt are used to farm, with the combination making up your total collateral on the platform 

As a result, you can farm on up to 2x notional (or more in Alpha V2), leveraging yields by 2x or more https://t.co/y5cg9QRuJ5

10/ On Compound, you deposit collateral and then borrow some asset which you custody and farm with 

As a result, you farm on only a fraction of your collateral value, reducing yields by 25-60% depending on LTV and how high a debt ratio you're comfortable with https://t.co/OhThBPzUeM

9/ As yield farming becomes an industry, leverage will become as important for farmers as it is for traders

If you’re borrowing to farm, using a platform like Alpha is far more efficient than a traditional money market like @compoundfinance. Why?

8/ While yields will come down over time, astute farmers will multiply them by choosing the right projects. The most ambitious farmers will look to get ahead by using leverage

That’s where Alpha Homora comes in

7/ Instead of insiders and VCs, the value will accrue to the wise farmers who pick the right crops and diligently tend to them, contributing resources to make the protocol successful https://t.co/PHkIbLpBMy

6/ When @coinbase IPO’d, founders and select silicon valley VCs owned the entire company 

While DeFi token distributions aren’t perfect, they’re much better than this with >50% often being reserved for the community

The Coinbases of DeFi will be community-owned https://t.co/pP5SnBnFfJ

5/ A question everyone asks is: where does the yield come from? 

The simple answer is speculation, as yields are sustained by those buying crop-coins 

The better answer is that yields come from the opportunity to own the futur of france

4/ Curve is a good example of a well-designed YF campaign which has resulted in the token being owned by its largest LPs, creating an in-built moat 

As our understanding evolves, more projects will opt for perpetual issuance, taxing passive holders in favour of active ones

3/ As explained below, a well-designed YF campaign creates a positive reflexive loop, transforming speculation into fundamentals, bootstrapping supply-sides and communities

We’ve already seen the success of this with @curve, @iearnfinance , @mirror_protocol and others

2/ Seen another way, YF dilutes passive tokenholders in favour of active holders that contribute to the project in some way

Over time, it results in user-owned projects, concentrating token ownership in the hands of MVP community members

1/ But first of all, what even is Yield Farming? 

At its simplest, YF involves a project distributing tokens directly to users for taking some on-chain action 

It makes sense because it allows projects to reward users for taking actions that benefit the protocol

Yield Farming is underestimated

I believe it represents the birth of a new industry, with farmers becoming a new kind of market participant

Now, I'm not a moonboi don't get me wrong. The current DeFi UX isn’t ready to swallow all of finance. Ethereum is too expensive, wallet UX is too shitty, and fiat on-ramps still suck

And yet, even the current incarnation of DeFi has sucked in $50B worth of value

TradFi:

- Highest “risk-free” yield available to most people is <1%
- Riddled with frictions like KYC/AML, awful bank UXs and general lack of innovation
- Your money is custodied by bankrupt banks and seizable by insolvent governments
- Opaque

TradFi is a government sanctioned monopoly where: 

- one entity (central bank) mints the cash 
- a few government licensed entities (banks) intermediate the way this cash is distributed to individuals 

Like all monopolies, it’s structurally inefficient

Crypto is a liquidity blackhole 

Everyone I introduce to the space starts off with 0-10% of their net worth invested and ends up with >50%. Even their cash moves to stables 

Other than aggressive regulation, I don’t see anything TradFi can do to reverse this trend https://t.co/7O6GwKodxc

12/12 Liquidity mining
 
In addition to standard pool 2 incentives, we also designed two separate incentive campaigns aimed at building up targeted liquidity for perps and options while avoiding wash trading https://t.co/8YRClakvOh

11/12 This means xPTF holders are incentivized to use the exchange to receive fee rebates and maximize utility of their token holdings 

OTOH, large exchange users are incentivized to become xPTF holders in order to reduce fee cost and maximize trading profits
10/12 Nevertheless, to further align incentives between DAO stakers and exchange users, we propose a tiered benefits system for stakers, pictured below https://t.co/fz9yItcK4F

9/12 The DAO could be incentivized to approve an overly optimistic risk framework in order to generate more profits for stakers. However, this would be as shortsighted as $NXM holders refusing to pay out claims

In the long-run, it will cause lack of trust in the exchange

8/12 The risk framework is a key piece of the system and should be considered carefully and monitored/updated regularly by governance

@Delphi_Digital has proposed an initial risk assessment methodology, but exploring it is outside the scope of this piece

7/12 25% of fees will flow to the DAO, split as follows: 

Before IF is sufficiently capitalized: 80% IF, 20% xPTF
After IF is sufficiently capitalized: 100% xPTF

The necessary capital ratio for the IF will be determined based on a risk framework to be approved by governors https://t.co/r28j2uxTg3

6/12 If a shortfall event occurs, the 3-tranche architecture kicks in:

1st  tranche: IF Fees Pool
2nd tranche: IF Staking Pool 
3rd tranche: xPTF staking pool (up to 30% auctioned off to cover deficit) 

If this isn't enough, the DAO can choose to mint PTF or issue debt tokens https://t.co/5Q03JCN9wB

5/12 The IF is the junior tranche, which will be built up over time via fee revenue from the exchange 

In the meanwhile, we will run an "insurance mining campaign", incentivizing USDC holders to stake into the IF in exchange for PTF rewards (h/t @DDX_Official for the idea) https://t.co/2848sh5A2v

4/12 We've taken this skin-in-the-game approach for $PTF

The DAO will be governed by PTF holders who stake into it, receiving xPTF which grants them governance and cashflow rights

xPTF also acts as the senior tranche,  backstopping claims which cannot be fully covered by the IF https://t.co/Mno8npCfHA

3/12 We believe protocols in which governors make risk decisions that affect 3rd parties (i.e. users) should ensure governors bear the consequences of their decisions, both positive and negative

@AaveAave's safety module is a great example of this principle in action

2/12 The high-level architecture consists of three main pieces:

🔹DAO
🔹Insurance Fund
🔹Exchange 

The DAO governs the insurance fund which underwrites the exchange, deciding on capital allocation, risk framework and assessing incoming claims https://t.co/XDSUS1Ryes

1/12 @PowerTradeHQ will initially operate as a CEX focusing on leveraged products including options and perps

Rather than do a burn/discount token a la $BNB / $FTT, Powertrade takes this a step further by tokenizing its insurance fund and putting it in the hands of $PTF holders

Leading up to today's Clubhouse, @Delphi_Digital  is excited to share our proposal for @PowerTradeHQ's token economics: https://t.co/fAqRVhgVdk

We see Powertrade's tokenized insurance fund as the next step in exchange token econ

We’ve only scratched the surface of what squads and DAOs can do

Permissonless, programmable cooperation will unlock new dimensions of how organisations operate and what they’re capable of

Many get stuck on the inefficiencies of current DAO models, but this is as silly as seeing Etherdelta in 2017 and dismissing all DEXes

Specialized tokenholder elected and accountable sub-committees will enable DAO decision-making to scale exponentially

Early examples of this are grants programs by @Uniswap , @compoundfinance and others

As they develop, grants will become viable alternatives for skilled builders whose opportunity cost is joining / starting their own early stage project

Successful DAOs will become talent black holes; meta-squads powered by systems of incentives which encourage other squads to permissionessly join the DAO and take ownership of some part of the project

Permissionless recruitment

Squads move quick and operate globally. As such, they require natively digital systems of cooperation 

DAOs will become the squad’s system of cooperation, just as the legal system was for previous orgs

See @RaidGuild, @dOrg_tech and @lex_DAO for inspiring early examples of this

Squads are greater than the sum of their parts

While in the short-term individual squad members may give up some upside, they understand the long-term compounding effects of leverage provided by a solid squad

"Long-term people playing long-term games"

https://t.co/Nmh4fkpqhM

Squads are more fluid than companies. There are no employment contracts, non-compete clauses, or 40 hr work weeks 

Squads are voluntary organisations, united by values enshrined in the squad's brand - a multifaceted digital coat of arms which attracts likeminded others

“SQUADS HAVE EXISTED FOR THOUSANDS OF YEARS as vital forms of social and economic organization. Thanks to group chats and a wave of private online social platforms, squads are reemerging today as a potent cultural force that rejects a strictly individualist market philosophy”

The entire crypto space is organised in squads 

Squads are groups of individuals which, united by common goals and shared values, gather virtually on Discord, TG or Discourse to do cool shit together

From the article:

🔥 article by @otherinternet__  on the fascinating concept of 'squads'

I believe 'squad' is the best term to describe the most successful organisations of the future 

I also believe DAOs will naturally become the squad operating system

12/ In addition to serving as an improved SM, these designs would also allow Aave to sell its streamed cover products to other projects/protocols 

We’re excited about the possibilities this presents and very much looking forward to hearing the community’s feedback on our ideas

11/ In the simpler model, users can only stake to the SM, underwriting all risks and receiving a blended return 

In the second case, users can boost SM returns by staking to specific contracts using leverage, taking on varying amounts of risk and being rewarded accordingly https://t.co/38RM855Zvo

10/ This is achieved by using a money market style architecture leveraging Aave’s current interest rate model to calculate cover pricing based on utilisation rate

Where the the designs differ is in terms of their supply-side experience. https://t.co/am0cbNdboI

9/ In both cases, users get access to one-click insurance with payment being streamed over time and netted out of deposit APYs rather than purchased upfront a la @NexusMutual and @CoverProtocol https://t.co/QWPyOCegxn

8/ Based on this insight, we propose two models: 

The first is a simplified, unlevered version which could act as an evolutionary step towards the second model which we see as the more efficient, final form design

7/ In our new design, insurance is instead offered as a separate product on the demand side 

This makes it possible to compute cover demand and capacity precisely and thus price risk using market mechanisms, scaling back some of the independence granted to aDAOs

6/ This, we hoped, would allow Aave to innovate quicker by segregating risk while incentivizing good decisions by the principle of skin in the game; ensuring those making decisions are forced to bear the potential downside if they are wrong

5/ Without a market based mechanism to price cover and therefore risk, our design instead offloaded these decisions to independent aDAOs who bore both the risk and reward of the money markets they managed 

They provided risk capital and earned fees in exchange for not blowing up

4/ Our initial proposal sought to improve on this current model while keeping the bundled insurance + money-market design 

This meant that demand for insurance was impossible to compute separately from money market demand https://t.co/cVhWTRSILJ

3/ This hampers the speed at which Aave can innovate by increasing the costs of failed experiments 

Finally, the current SM is capital inefficient since it is unlevered and bundles different risks to offer a blended return, appealing to a narrower capital base

2/ Because insurance is bundled in with Aave's money markets, it's impossible to compute cover demand, pricing, capacity or how much to pay underwriters

Any new money market added is also automatically insured by the SM, introducing unlimited contagion and systemic risk

1/ Before diving into our proposal it's important to understand how the current Aave Safety Module (SM) works

The SM is an insurance product which underwrites all risks (SC, oracle and liquidation) for all users of Aave protocol 

As an insurance product, it has a few flaws https://t.co/1zXtfBHKMH
