25/ It goes without saying that both DEXes and insurance have massive upside from here given the growth we expect in DeFi as a whole - we are interested in speaking with and investing in teams in both sectors

Disclaimer: Delphi Ventures is an investor in $RUNE, $NXM and Debank

24/ While an imperfect comparison, it's worth remembering that in the real world insurance is  a $6.3T industry and the largest segment within financial services alongside banking. Exchanges are far smaller by any measure

23/ While both insurance and exchange will be massive sectors, we see insurance as being better positioned to capture value long-term 

This is not reflected in prices right now as the cumulative market cap of DEXes is $2.7B compared to only ~$230M for insurance

22/ ...e.g. protocol insurance for treasuries 

Large capital pools can underwrite proprietary cover, diversifying their liabilities and enabling greater diversification. This in turn provides greater efficiency, generating the familiar network effect flywheel

21/ Non-linear liquidity network effect 

Unlike exchanges, the liquidity network effect for an insurance product scales non-linearly in that a platform with more liquidity does not just offer better pricing but is also capable of underwriting entirely new types of risks...

20/ This is also why we remain bearish on prediction market based insurance models which are capitalized 1:1

As we see it, these models will always remain either expensive for cover buyers or provide low yields to LPs

19/ Leverage can only be achieved by underwriting diversified risks 

As such, not only is stealing liquidity difficult, new entrants will struggle to compete on price even if they attract liquidity as they will not have the diversification necessary to enable leverage

18/ Diversification & Efficiency  

Unlike exchanges in which efficiency depends almost solely on liquidity, for insurance protocols efficiency relies on leverage: using $1 of capital to underwrite >$1 worth of risk
17/ This brand moat can only be developed over years of paying out claims and cannot be forked or vampire attacked away

16/ Differentiated Demand  

Unlike exchanges in which traders care primarily about best execution and have little to no brand loyalty, insurance platforms are chosen based not just on pricing but also on a user’s confidence in the platform's ability to pay out

15/ In addition, supply-siders have skin in the game and must accurately assess claims to ensure the long-term growth of the platform 

This is very different from an LP passively providing liquidity in an AMM

14/ Differentiated supply

Since insurance cover is underwritten for a given period of time, supply-side liquidity is less fluid as there must always be enough capacity to pay out existing claims (i.e. @NexusMutual's MCR)

13/ Now let’s compare this with insurance. Liquidity is also a moat for insurance in that more liquidity means greater capacity. 

However, insurance has several additional moats

12/ As such, an exchange’s moat is liquidity since this means better execution, higher trading fees and better yield for LPs 

However, liquidity is fluid and will flow towards the highest yield. Rent extraction to tokenholders hampers execution/yield and thus the exchange's moat

11/ While the supply side provides greater opportunity for differentiation on things like algorithm optimisations (@BreederDodo ), flexibility (@BalancerLabs ), types of assets (@thorchain_org ), LPs are still primarily interested in optimising yield

10/ While some users may interact with their favourite DEXes directly, we feel aggregators such as @1inchExchange , @DeBankDeFi will increasingly dominate since they allow users to get best execution on trades across all active DEXes

9/ As I argued in my piece on DEX Wars and Aggregation Theory, DEX liquidity is “undifferentiated supply”, meaning it is highly price elastic as most traders care only about best execution 

https://t.co/53isZzDfGY
8/ We will now apply our framework to two different sectors: decentralised exchanges and insurance, focusing primarily on the second and third tests

7/ Good investments must pass all three tests, a daunting task made more difficult by the open, forkable nature of projects in the space 

I believe #few in the space currently think about investments in these terms, leading to significant mispricings

6/ The third test is the one traditional investors have least experience with 

Unlike equity which is likely to be valuable if the project passes the first 2 tests, the value of a token depends entirely on its design. Each token is different and must be analysed independently

5/ Ideally, as investors we want projects with multiple, compounding, unforkable moats that cumulatively mean the project has some form of increasing returns to scale, meaning it gets more difficult to unseat the bigger it is

https://t.co/bctycuSaBb

4/ The second test is tougher. In traditional markets, investors can get away with being less rigorous about this as proprietary technology and strong teams can pose moats 

Crypto's open nature means only network effects provide reliable long-term defensibility

3/ The first test is the easiest in the sense that it’s one investors in traditional markets are already used to making

Is the product useful and does it have product-market fit? Is the team experienced and capable?

2/

👉 Will the project be able to capture value from those users and establish a long-term, defensible moat?

👉 Will the value captured accrue to the token? https://t.co/jB9NnXOUOh

One of the book's most vocal fans was @VitalikButerin himself, and the two have since collaborated extensively including the original Quadratic Funding paper which spawned @gitcoin

Glen reminds us that the ideas that now make up economic dogma once seemed radical, referred to as the so-called "Marginal Revolution" of the late 19th century

The same open mind is required to come up with new solutions for the unprecedented times we live in

As a result of this first principles approach, many of his solutions seem truly "radical" and new in that they combine seemingly "socialist" ideas (private property is monopoly) with seemingly "capitalist" ones (markets for political influence)

I learned a lot from this book, but my main takeaway was realising the design space for economic solutions is much broader than the narrow neoclassical toolset I was taught at University

In simple terms, Glen seeks to bring markets to democracy, and democracy to markets

9/9 It's worth remembering that unlike with other DeFi protocols, liquidity provides an actual moat for Nexus since MCR is locked at 100%

This gives Nexus a headstart in the form of a large supply of capital to focus on what matters: generating cover demand

8/9 Despite the MCR cucking as @DegenSpartan so aptly puts it, we still see @NexusMutual as the most efficient insurance model in DeFi right now

Its strong brand, $85M capital pool and diversified cover exposure represent real moats that upstarts will have to overcome

6/9 As such, a dedicated insurance protocol like @NexusMutual that underwrites risk across the space (and eventually outside of it) must always exist and will likely always be more efficient than specialised insurance pools

5/9 The only way for projects to avoid this is to diversify, offering cover to other projects

Not only is this not their core competency, they are also competing with Nexus's existing diversified capital pool which enables more leverage and better rates

4/9 Risks across the crypto space are already highly correlated, but this is even more pronounced within a particular credit protocol since: 

🔸smart contracts are all built by the same people 
🔸the same oracles used in the same way across protocol
🔸risk framework is uniform

3/9 While we believe this makes a lot of sense as a token model, we don't think it is competitive but rather complementary to @NexusMutual 

This is because insurance relies on leverage to be efficient and leverage requires diversified, uncorrelated risk exposures

2/9

🔸Transforms idle market cap into balance sheet, generating fees
🔸Risks can be bundled into products and offered to users based on their particular preferences

1/9 I believe most DeFi credit protocols like will end up creating their own insurance pool underwritten by tokenholders. Why? 

🔸Gives governors skin in the game and an incentive to make good decisions
🔸Better product for users who want insurance as they deposit

5/12 Projects such as @synthetix_io have exemplified the positive effects that locking up users can have on a community and on bootstrapping a supply-side and we feel there are lessons to be learned here

Our proposal seeks to achieve this with 3 steps:

4/12 To align incentives, we propose paying a higher premium to $ANJ holders who are willing to lock up their converted $ANT, signalling their long-term commitment to the Court

$ANJ holders who want to exit are still allowed to do so but this should entail a much lower premium

3/12 From our perspective, the worst case outcome for everyone is a contentious $ANJ fork in which the community is split and Aragon Protocol now has a competitor with the same name (Aragon Court Classic?). Avoiding this outcome is crucial and, our research indicates, achievable

2/12 Crucially, this must be done while appropriately rewarding $ANJ holders to reward their early belief in the Court, reflect the upside they’re now giving up and, most importantly, avoid splintering the burgeoning community

1/12 While initially we favoured $ANJ independence, our conversations over the last few weeks convinced us that the best path forward to avoid protracted negotiations, align incentives and enable the Court to be successful is to merge $ANJ into $ANT

10/10 You can read the full 32-page proposal on our website here: https://t.co/PfILiS58Xx

Or the shortened version on Aave governance forums here: https://t.co/24znWRxxmM 

We look forward to receiving feedback from the community and iterating together towards the best solution

9/10 We believe this proposal advances @AaveAave toward becoming a credit protocol rather than a credit facility

Our goal is for Aave to become the go-to platform for launching, growing and managing money markets, benefitting from Aave's existing network effects and scale

8/10 Complexity is abstracted away from end-users and UX is improved as Aave can move faster and offer a greater variety of insured money markets 

Risks are siloed and contained among those who are willing to bear them and appropriately rewarded for doing so ($aDAO holders)

7/10 Crucially, while the aDAOs govern and backstop risk for their own money-markets, the user always interacts with the Aave front-end and smart contracts 

This ensures Aave controls the user relationship and TVL, increasing fork-resistance and ecosystem wide network effects https://t.co/MipxlabpuD

5/10 While the aDAO is self-sovereign, it does not itself control the smart contracts of its money-market

Instead, any decision made by the aDAO is sent to the Aave DAO to ratify and execute. This ensures TVL always sits with Aave, maximising the ecosystem-wide network effects.

4/10 aDAOs are self-sovereign and governed by $aDAO holders 

$aDAO tokens are minted on a bonding curve by locking up $AAVE as the reserve asset. The $AAVE on the bonding curve acts as the safety pool underwiting the risk in that aDAO's money markets

3/10 Our proposal eliminates the system-wide safety pool and replaces it with sharded safety pools in the form of aaveDAOs (aDAOs) 

Each aDAO governs its own money markets and underwrites the specific, pre-defined risks associated with those money markets

2/10 This enables more nimble competitors such as @CreamdotFinance to steal market share, innovating quicker by adding new, riskier products

It's also capital inefficient, bundling different risks together and offering a blended return, appealing to a narrower capital base

1/10 We believe the current design with a single, undifferentiated safety pool is flawed

Firstly, it hampers innovation by increasing the potential costs of failed new product experiments as these can cause contagion and systemic risk https://t.co/hkIljntL0q

11/ Ultimately, the vision of the world of self-sovereign individuals that both the BTC and DeFi communities believe in requires both BTC and DeFi to succeed

Rather than bicker, let's embrace the different methodologies and #buidl towards this vision together

10/ An autonocratic approach might be the right way to build digital gold as robustness, predictability and security should be prioritised over everything else

However, it is not the right approach to innovation or iterating on early stage technology (i.e. DeFi)

9/ While Bitcoin and DeFi tend to clash philosophically, with the former prioritising immutability (autonocratic) and the latter upgradeability (anthropocratic), it's worth remembering that different goals require different approaches

8/ There is already over $1B of Bitcoin on Ethereum being used to earn yield on AMMs, deposited as collateral and borrowed

As the ecosystem and technology develop, we expect Bitcoin’s utility to rise exponentially, increasing its liquidity and network effect https://t.co/6caaHad4Zt

7/ While short-term BTC strength may pull liquidity from DeFi, long-term it attracts more capital to the space, increasing liquidity and demand for Bitcoin utility provided by DeFi

Similarly, the growth of DeFi is good for BTC because it increases its utility and network effect

6/ While $USDT is currently the most liquid asset in DeFi, it inherits the dollar's monetary policy and we are bearish on its long-term prospects

We see BTC as the leading contender to become the base trading pair and reserve asset of the financial system of the future

5 We see DeFi as building the open, borderless, trustless financial infrastructure of the future 

However, this financial infrastructure is useless without liquidity and liquidity ultimately comes from assets people want

4/ While the current iteration sits mostly on Ethereum and uses bridge tech with significant centralisation vectors among many other flaws, focusing on this is missing the forest for the trees

This is early stage tech and will continue to progress quickly

3/ This is where DeFi comes in 

DeFi is our first legit attempt at building the decentralised infrastructure that can give Bitcoin its utility without rendering it someone else's liability

2/ Bitcoin is not only a financial asset that is no one else’s liability, it can also be used as part of a broader financial system without becoming someone else’s liability 

Rather than trust a counterparty, users need only trust cryptoeconomic incentives and human greed

1/11 Bitcoin can be seen as "Digital Gold", with its like for like characteristics as a store of value being superior in every way

However, it's also much more than this as it's natively digital nature enables programmability, utility and financial innovation at software speed https://t.co/gIDHZf7mqR

10/10 Being an absolute Chad and having 95% of your net worth in crypto is cool if you're ok with the risks 

That said, some rebalancing makes sense and can also lead to better investment and life outcomes if it means you're less stressed and able sleep better at night

9/10 Finally, crypto is a highly +EV bet but if you don't think theres a significant chance of failure, you're kidding yourself

For most of us working + investing in the space, our net worths are already extremely correlated to crypto prices

8/10 At the same time, one shouldn't be afraid to let go of an investment if the thesis has materially changed. But this shouldn't happen more often during downturns

If anything, it should happen more during upturns as the investment becomes more expensive and therefore riskier

7/10 After all, price is just a single and often extremely noisy, data point about an investment. Its movements up or down should not meaningfully impact the thesis

Beware of the rationalisations for selling that spring up during downturns

6/10 At best, drawdowns can help prompt one to question the thesis and (hopefully) come back more convicted

Occasionally they may prompt a reevaluation of the thesis, but if one is investing based on fundamentals this should imo be rare

5/10 No matter what anyone tells you, 50%+ drawdowns are no fun

However, the fundamentals themselves rarely change that much in such short periods of time and so neither should one's investments

4/10 Obviously, one should take advantage of this liquidity as it allows for rebalancing. Most importantly, it also makes outcomes less binary and thus less volatile than traditional VC

However, one should not let the liquidity take advantage of us

3/10 A look at any of the best performing public stocks will show you that you cannot have 10-1000x upside potential without volatiliy and occasional large drawdowns 

Crypto, as early stage tech, is much riskier than established public companies and thus even higher vol too

2/10 As with all early stage tech, realising these outcomes will require 4-8 year holds

Unlike early stage tech, crypto investors will have liquidity, i.e. the possibility, and thus the temptation, to sell  

This is both a blessing and a curse

1/10 Imo, some DeFi projects represent 10-1000x upside opportunities

Obviously, like all of crypto, it is extremely risky and can go to 0. That said, given the magnitude of potential outcomes, it just doesn't have to succeed that often to make it a massively +EV bet

While my time investing in crypto and previously playing poker has gotten me used to experiencing large daily personal net worth volatility, it's never a pleasant experience

All DeFi protocols will be in the line of fire as they grow and become more economically significant

17/17 YFI's community meant it generated the best strategies, attracting most liquidity. The best strategists are attracted to the highest liquidity which maximises the amount of fees they can earn. This creates a reflexive, compounding, positive flywheel effect

16/17 As mentioned earlier, truly defensible moats come from combining multiple unforkable attributes

We've already discussed @thorchain_org earlier which combines liquidity and security, but another example here is @iearnfinance which combines liquidity and community

15/17 A protocol with a significant amount of integrations becomes very difficult to fork since these integrations must be built one by one and require time and trust 

A good example here is @MakerDAO 's DAI which, despite its flaws, is integrated everywhere and hard to displace

14/17 Integrations 

If liquidity is unforkable supply, integrations are unforkable demand 

Unlike the other unforkable attributes, integrations can also be proprietary in that they often rely on proprietary relationships (e.g. exchange listings)

13/17 While there are no shortcuts to building strong communities, a well-designed token economic model can be a useful tool 

An example of this is @synthetix_io which, which used locked incentives to nurture one of the most active, long-term oriented communities in the space

12/17 While liquidity mining has shown that at least some community members will defect given sufficiently high incentives, it has also shown that many will not. 

One example here is @AaveAave which despite no liquidity mining incentives has attracted higher TVL and MC than COMP

11/17 Community 

Most DeFi protocols either are or aim to one day become user-owned public goods. As such, their progress and success is in a large part dependent on the size and quality of the user bases that govern them

10/17 Forks cannot simply redeploy the smart contracts, they must also deploy a new token and bootstrap enough liquidity and security to compete

Also, as liq flows out of RUNE, the competitor must contend with RUNE’s automated incentives, increasing the costs of forking

9/17 The protocol also utilises an incentive pendulum to ensure this remains the case, increasing the portion of liquidity fees that nodes receive when the ratio drops below 3:1, providing strong incentives for more nodes to come online

This provides built-in fork resistance... https://t.co/v9oBkkt90V

8/17 Value of RUNE bonded by nodes must always be > 3:1 ratio to value of external TVL

As the value of bonded RUNE increases, the capacity of the network (amount of external TVL it can facilitate) increases which means more liquidity, security and value accrual for RUNE
7/17 In well-designed token economic systems such as @thorchain_org , security is proportional to the market cap of the network and thus intrinsically linked to supply-side liquidity

6/17 Security 

Security can be seen as the cost of undermining a protocol’s consensus: the higher the cost, the more secure the protocol is

Higher security attracts more demand, generating better yield for supply-siders and contributing to the network effect flywheel effect

5/17 However, as we’ve seen with recent vampire attacks by Sushi and others, liquidity is a fickle mistress, flowing to wherever the highest incentives are

As such, it cannot be used in isolation but must be combined with another unforkable attribute to provide a sustained moat

4/17 Specifically, greater supply-side liquidity (e.g. depositors in Aave/COMP, LPs in Uniswap/Balancer, stakers in SNX) leads to higher capacity/better prices which begets more demand-side usage, fees and greater supply-side liquidity

3/17 Liquidity 💧

Most DeFi products are two-sided market places with supply of capital on one side and demand on the other. As such, they benefit from marketplace liquidity network effects.

2/17 I argue there are four distinct network effects present in DeFi: liquidity (weak), security, community and integrations

In order to be defensible, a project must leverage a combination of these attributes, with the whole being greater than the sum of its parts...

1/17 While DeFi fulfils most of the conditions of a perfectly competitive market, unlike in perfect competition projects in DeFi are not price-takers because they benefit from network effects, meaning as they grow they are able to price out competitors

Unlike in traditional markets, in DeFi almost everything is forkable 🍴, making it difficult to establish a moat

In today's @Delphi_Digital daily, I discuss the attributes that *can't* be forked and how to combine and compound them to create unassailable moats 🏰

(27/27) We see the top echelon of DeFi projects having the ability to significantly outperform even during periods of extreme macro instability



During those times, we hope you can return to this post, remind yourself of how early we still are, and HODL!

(26/27) To recap, we’re still at the very beginning of DeFi with explosive growth potential ahead of us



That said, it’s important to realise DeFi’s relationship to the global macro environment which may lead to short/medium term volatility

(25/27) Finally, we’re extremely excited about the innovation happening in the gaming and NFT space, as we still believe incentivized virtual economies are a natural environment for crypto to flourish, unlocking massive innovation and value for gamers

(24/27) @AaveAave recently received its Electronic Money Institution License in the UK and preparing to launch tokenised mortgages 

We’ve spoken to many strong teams looking to bridge the real world via crypto savings accounts, and will announce an investment in this space soon

(23/27) The circularity of the DeFi ecosystem means all projects are tethered to this until we manage to break into real world adoption

While it’s still early, we believe this real world adoption is closer than ever before

(22/27) Just as Yield Farming causes positive reflexive loops on the way up (as speculation leads to higher yield and improving fundamentals in the form of more supply-siders and consequently demand-siders), the inverse happens on the way down

(21/27) While we see crypto, led by BTC, eventually decoupling from the stock market and risk assets more broadly, this is still a ways away

DeFi sits in the highest risk pocket in an already high risk crypto space and is extremely vulnerable to the global macro situation

(20/27) Strong dollar is bearish for risk assets and potentially signals the beginnings of deflation and the insolvency phase @Kevin_Kelly_II and I described in our macro piece earlier this year 

https://t.co/cABqAXfCyK

(19/27) Dazzled by recent stock market and risk asset surges, many underestimate the very real probability of a post-COVID solvency crisis

Key recovery indicators peaked in June and this is reflected in the dollar which has broken out of its descending channel https://t.co/D0hVxzr1Dv

(18/27) All this said, it's important to note that crypto sits at the very edge of the risk curve and is thus extremely sensitive to the global macro situation

A move towards deflation will pose serious headwinds for crypto broadly and DeFi specifically

(17/27) Indeed, even if no new money enters the space, we see this repricing being corrected by the market as money flows towards the only vertical in crypto showing signs of product market fit

However, it will be a bumpy ride as you can't have massive upside without volatility

(16/27) In comparison, the cumulative market caps of largely inactive Layer 1 projects like Ripple, Bitcoin Cash, Bitcoin SV, Litecoin, EOS, Cardano, Tron, Stellar, NEO and NEM is ~$32B https://t.co/Dhr6ka38y7

(15/27) Finance is the world’s largest market for consumer software and DeFi's TAM is estimated in the trillions of dollars

To put this in perspective, the cumulative market cap of DeFi is currently at $13.5B

(14/27) Similar to the internet, new token-based business models will not only collapse the cost of financial services but also make them accessible to a much broader swath of people, while creating entirely new and unforeseen use cases and applications

(13/27) It's important to remember the value prop for DeFi is doing to finance what the internet did to data 

Transforming financial primitives into “Money Legos” and creating an open ecosystem that enables permissionless innovation

(12/27) This maps on well to @CarlotaPrzPerez's framework for technological revolutions, in which a frenzy and bubble is proceeded by a crash, during which the buidlers buidl and sow the seeds for the next phase of growth. https://t.co/BJ6XNZnshX

(11/27) Leaders like @AaveAave  and @synthetix_io (formerly Ethlend and Havven) were funded via 2017 ICOs, and after iterating through a bear market that saw their prices drop >95%, both have landed on products with product market fit and vastly surpassed their ICO valuations

(10/27) These are two examples of many I could cite

The key takeaway is that this DeFi boom is bringing with it real innovation and value. This is dramatically different from what was happening in the ICO boom where the vast majority of projects didn’t even have a live product

(9/27) On the other side, projects like @yearn have shown the power of yield farming and fair launches in bootstrapping an insanely strong community consisting of many of the smartest people in the space (the "Citadel")

Together, they've created a behemoth with nearly $1B AUM

(8/27) We've already seen a couple of examples of this, with @CurveFinance attracting over $1B in liquidity and offering better execution than CEXes on some of its pairs, an idea unthinkable even a few months ago https://t.co/4bRu7xzZRW

(7/27) This incentivizes the bootstrapping of the supply-side of a network, driving down costs on the demand-side 

If executed properly, it also creates a community of users who all have skin in the game and are incentivized to contribute their time and ideas to the project

(6/27) Rather than merely distributing tokens to those willing to pay for them as with ICOs, yield farming distributes tokens to the actual users of the network, incentivizing them to contribute work, time and ideas.
(5/27) However, the genius of Yield Farming is that it manages to transform crypto’s inherent fondness for speculation into fundamentals, growth and community, creating a positive reflexive loop

(4/27) While in the ICO boom this was reflected in rapid price appreciation, it’s now reflected in astronomical APYs, paid out in crop coins whose price is sustained by those unfortunate enough to buy rather than farm

(3/27) Before we dive into differences, let me start by admitting that ultimately much of the “yield” currently available in DeFi is subsidized by the same exact dynamic that powered the ICO boom: speculating on overpriced shitcoins.

(2/27) For those who lived through the ICO madness, the recent food coin high season 🍣🍠 🍝 may bring flashbacks of the futility coin fuelled 2017 boom (ht @Obstropolos) 

While the underlying mechanism is the same, there are some fundamental differences worth exploring

(1/27) First, it's important to realise speculation has always been crypto's killer app

The ICO boom was only the most extreme example, but crypto's history is dotted with boom and bust cycles, dating back to 2013 and Namecoin, Mastercoin (now Omni) and Maidsafe https://t.co/gtWorMqgwg

With the yield farming craze and recent market drop, we've begun to hear calls of a so-called "DeFi Bubble", with a few arguing DeFi has topped

In today's daily, I take a longer term view and look at YF, DeFi vs ICO boomand where I think we are in the cycle

(15/15) Most importantly, we also remain bullish on crypto projects’ ability to adapt and reinvent themselves, and it’s certainly possible that AMMs use their liquidity to expand into new markets with more defensible moats (e.g. pegged tokens)
(14/15) In all cases, we remain bullish on AMMs that can build meaningful supply-side differentiation or those that have tokens that serve a genuinely necessary role in the ecosystem

(13/15) To be clear, we believe all AMMs have tremendous short and medium-term upside given the overall growth of DeFi and crypto markets more broadly 

However, it’s important to keep in mind the long-term dynamics and these projects’ ability to establish defensible moats

(12/15) In addition:

a) proposals like this are only possible because LPs are currently subsidised by 35%-90% APYs, a practice unlikely to be sustainable

b) the increased value extraction opens up opportunities for lower-cost competitors to gain market share

(11/15) I use the example of Curve, which while extremely successful, is currently generating only a 0.73% yield for its LPs and 0% for CRV holders

Even if all fee income were redirected to CRV governance as per @Rewkang's proposal, this would represent a 0.073% yield

(10/15) Given these networks are open and forkable 🍴, that both VCs and retail investors are content to continue subsidising governance token launches, it's likely competition will remain high

By consequence, the ability for leaders to exert market power will remain low

(9/15) While liquidity is a network effect/moat since it provides better execution (similar to how scale with airlines helps amortise fixed costs), any value extraction by governance token holders will immediately hamper execution and thus the size of their moat

(8/15) In my second post, I question the value of AMM governance tokens, asking whether AMMs will end up being the "Airlines of Crypto" ✈️, attracting large investment, generating massive revenue, but converting this into consumer surplus rather than profitability https://t.co/2UHrZtDMRw

(7/15) In my first post, I describe some of the supply-side differentiators we feel will provide enduring moats

These include: cross-chain capabilities, mitigating impermanent loss, algorithm optimisations, flexibility & features, token economics and UX

(6/15) As such, it must be accompanied by strong product-market fit, i.e. the ability to retain the liquidity generated

In addition, liquidity mining will be table stakes for new DEXes launching and is thus unlikely to provide an enduring moat

(5/15) While liquidity mining incentives may work to bootstrap early adoption and network effects, what the past few months' experiment has already shown us is that liquidity is hyper fluid and will go to wherever the highest yield is

(4/15) Crucially, this means that a DEX’s customer is not the trader but rather the LP 

This being the case, in order to differentiate themselves, build a moat 🏰, and win their markets, DEXes must focus on owning their supply-side

(3/15) Liquidity💧 is what's called "undifferentiated supply", meaning it is highly price elastic as most traders care only about best execution

We thus expect the demand side of the DEX market to be mostly commoditised, with consumers interacting via aggregators vs single DEXes

(2/15) A similar phenomenon is happing with DEXes 

While initially users interacted with their favourite DEX directly, aggregators such as 1inchexchange, https://t.co/9QR7aFKpbP and others have emerged allowing users to get best execution on trades across all active DEXes https://t.co/6ABHVKIkYB

(1/15) Aggregation theory, first suggested by @stratechery, describes how the internet changed value capture by commoditising distribution

Thus, suppliers could build direct relationships with consumers cheaply. Consumer choice exploded, necessitating the rise of aggregators

For my last two @Delphi_Digital dailies, I touched on DEXes, aggregation theory and long-term value capture, questioning whether AMMs are set to become the Airlines of Crypto.

(7/7) Prisoner's dilemmas normally require some sort of regulation. 

In the aftermath of this crisis, what are some solutions we can 
implement to make our systems more resilient? How can crypto networks play a part in this?

(6/7) As nice as resilience sounds, businesses face a prisoner's dilemma: In the long-term, if you're not resilient you die. In the short-term, if you don't maximise efficiency you get outcompeted and you die, never making it to the long run.

(5/7) Resilience on the other hand requires redundancy and waste, sacrificing efficiency for longevity. It means less specialised, local supply chains, cash reserves, limited leverage and profitability before growth.
(4/7) Central banks pre-emptively lowers rates with markets near ATH to ensure economies operate at "full capacity", giving them less ammo when actually needed.

(3/7) In pursuit of efficiency, we run fragmented and highly specialised supply chains, yielding lower prices but exposing us to single points of failure. 

Companies operate with high leverage, boosting profitability in good times but making them vulnerable to bad times.
(2/7) Efficiency involves maximising the amount of output generated per unit of input. Under this approach, waste and redundancy are shunned.

Efficiency vs resilience. A thread 👇

(1/7) Chamath Palihapitiya got me thinking about efficiency, resilience, and how our approach to business will change post #COVID19

Overall, it seems to me that if we reduce commitment costs and assume that a lower p(PostAttackPrice) might actually increase MEV due to the possibility of shorting, the incentives of the attacker and security model of BTC start to look a lot worse.

Relatedly, I also wonder about the assumption that p(followNC) will lower the MEV. While it will lower the MEV of a direct attack, it could correlate with lower p(PostAttackPrice) due to disruption caused to the network and thus increase the MEV of a BTC short position attack.
Given this, I'm not sure p(PostAttackPrice) will actually lower MEV or increase commitment costs as, depending on the type of attack, the relationship could actually be the opposite.

(2) is only true if you assume there are such a thing as "non-repurposable assets" which as I showed above is a pretty dodgy assumption as attacker can mine something else or keep mining BTC (assuming it doesn't die).

(1) is only true if the attacker is seeking to profit directly via the attack. If the attacker is instead seeking to profit by shorting BTC, p(Postattackprice) could actually make mEV larger (multiples larger depending on depth of derivatives market and leverage)

Another core assumption is that a lower "p(PostAttackPrice)" will: (1) reduce MEV (since the price at the attacker could sell the stolen BTC is lower) and (2) Reduce the value of the non-repurposable assets (since MR for the lifetime of the assets would be reduced).

This being the case, these costs do not seem completely "sunk" to me which significantly reduces "commitment costs" figures and consequently reduces the hurdle rate for Miner Extractable Value significantly - making attacks much more attractive than the model currently reflects.

c) Even if hardware couldn't be repurposed, it's not clear to me that a DS attack would actually kill BTC (see ETC, BCH and XVG). If so, the hardware would not immediately become valueless as the attacker could continue mining on the (less valuable) but still alive BTC chain.

b) It seems to me even hardware costs could potentially be repurposed as we can imagine a scenario where a competing chain forks its mining algorithm to take advantage of the huge spare capacity that would be caused by BTC going down

However, I'm not sure this assumption is valid for a few reasons: 

a) the facility, PPA's and everything other than hardware are not sunk costs since these can be repurposed to mine some other coin

Firstly, the security model seems to rely on a core assumption, namely the fact that miners face sunk "commitment costs" (facilities, hardware, PPAs, etc) and that roughly 50% of the total costs of mining are held in these non-repurposable, sunk cost assets.

While thinking long-term to try solve species-level extinction problems is admirable and important, I think there's also a place for shorter-term thinking that aims to raise human consciousness and prepare us for the responsibility that AI and tools like it will bestow upon us.

All this said, while I don't think AI will take over, it will certainly greatly magnify our power. This increased power must be accompanied by improvements in education, political and economic organization/governance and human character more generally.

I applaud Elon's efforts in trying to advance this collaborative vision through Neuralink, but I also sympathize with Jack that we should be more "confident" about our unique abilities as humans and not seek to compete or compare ourselves with machines in data processing.

This being the case, while AI is undoubtedly a superior computation machine, as long as we agree intelligence is far more than a data processing problem, there will always be room for human intelligence, for now guiding/training but eventually evolving symbiotically alongside AI.

I would actually go further and argue that the majority of what's good/useful about human intelligence, our flexibility and creativity (which allowed us to come up with AI in the first place), isn't an output of data processing but rather knowledge gained from "experience".

The intelligence that can be achieved by AI will therefore always be incomplete, since even if it is fed all the data there is about the world, there will always remain a rich, vast realm of "experience" which will be unknown to AI.

Now let's say we release Mary from her white and black room or is given a colour TV monitor. Will she learn anything new? To me, the response to this question is obviously yes, and demonstrates that there is something about "experience" that cannot be captured in data.

Mary is a brilliant scientist who is, for some reason, trapped in a black and white room. She specializes in the neurophysiology of vision and acquires all the physical data there is about what goes on when we see ripe tomatoes, or the sky, or the colour "red", and so on.

From my perspective, the "inputs" that feed into intelligence derive from what I call "experience" which is much broader than that which can be translated into data. To see this, we need only look at the famous thought experiment referred to as "Mary in the Black and White Room"

The entire disagreement rests on this premise. Elon argues machines are superior data processors and will thus eventually become vastly more intelligent; Jack argues there is something about human intelligence that is incomensurable, and in some sense, superior, to AI.

Underlying Elon's argument is the unstated premise that humans are like computers, with "bandwidth", "compute", "input" and "output", and that what we call "intelligence" is therefore merely a data processing problem, a domain in which we will never compete with machines.

@Shaughnessy119 I agree with this long-term but think right now the EF has enough funding for a few years and, given this change would require some pretty significant transparency and governance redesign, I'd rather they focus on getting ETH 2.0 out first.

The biggest advantage Ethereum's other competitors have is the fact most of them haven't yet launched and therefore haven't had the opportunity to disappoint people's expectations. Once they do, I suspect many of them will face the same issues Ethereum has.

All this said, it seems fairly clear to me that at current prices Ethereum is still the best bet in the smart contracting platform space. The only one that comes close in terms of risk reward profile in my mind is Tezos.

Don't get me wrong, it's still very unclear whether the "Defi" and "Web 3.0" narratives that underly the Smart Contract Platform investment thesis will actually play out. Also, Ethereum hasn't done itself any favours with the delays and lack of transparency to tokenholders

While it's difficult to come up with absolute valuations given the lack of reliable fundamental indicators, in relative terms it seems crazy that EOS is worth 1/3rd of Ethereum despite 10x less active developers or that Dffinity is worth 1/8th despite not even having launched

It's crazy to me that we're now in a world where being long Ether is contrarian, despite the fact Ethereum is still the clear market leader with way more dApps, brand recognition, network value and most importantly: developer mindshare.

@spencernoon @jlppfeffer Velocity will lead to poor value capture mechanics, as seen by Pfeffer's example in this comment: https://t.co/zXj4xl41r2. ETH will thus have low market cap compared to economic activity/tx volume denominated in it.

@spencernoon @jlppfeffer Since protocols will be frictionless, open-source and forkable, users will not need to hold ETH as they can easily acquire it when they need to use it and sell it straight afterwards, leading to extremely high velocity.

@spencernoon @jlppfeffer Given opportunity costs of capital, agents will always try and minimize working capital and the amount they hold will depend on friction, latency and uncertainty of replenishment (i.e. how difficult it is and how long it takes to acquire more of it).
@spencernoon @jlppfeffer Basically, if an asset is used to pay for smart contracting utility, then it is working capital.

Step 9: At this point, customers will have been unknowingly onboarded onto public chains and the open finance ecosystem. As such, the bank’s additional services such as credit, investment banking, etc begin to be disrupted as well.

Step 8:  As a result, the utility and innovation on the public chains far outpaces that of the bank’s coins and most people move to using some public blockchain token, moving in and out of the bank’s private coin only as necessary to interact with the bank’s apps.

Step 7: Banks struggle to compete since: a) they're notoriously bad at interoperability b) the number of developers they can hire to build apps ontop of this will pale compared to developer activity on open source, permissionless blockchains (ie Intranets vs Internet).

Step 6: Banks realise that in order for their stable coins to be truly useful to customers, they need to interoperate and more importantly they need to enable innovation by developers who will work to build out more applications and utility for the ecosystem.

Step 5: Public chains bootstrap the cryptocurrency adoption driven by banks and build an interoperability layer, integrating and linking together the various bank stablecoins to each other and to the (hopefully by that point more developed) open finance stack.

Step 4:Knowing banks, interoperability between these coins will suck and you'll only ever be able to send money to people from your own bank. UX will probably suck too as will the amount and quality of applications built ontop of these coins.

Step 3: Crucially, no bank wants to agree to use a competitor's coin built on a competitor's chain and they all launch their own coins/chains. Knowing banks, interoperability between these coins will suck and you'll only ever be able to send money to people from your own bank.
Step 2: As the tech improves, banks begin to allow retail customers to send money to each other using JPCoin.

Step 1: Banks like JPMorgan launch their own cryptocurrencies, stablecoins backed by and redeemable to dollars, built on private blockchains and initially used only to improve settlement times and efficiencies between corporations and banks.

@cburniske 3) As Mark C Taylor said when explaining the death of God (which he compared to the abolition of the gold standard): "Gold is a sign which denies its status as a sign in order to ground the value of other signs".

@cburniske 2) In a way, the "fundamentalness" of DCF valuations is granted by the fact that their cashflows can be compared to and therefore grounded by this so-called "risk-free rate". Imo the role played by this is similar to the one played by gold for currencies before 1971

@cburniske Imo, the difference between crypto models and DCFs is that the former are relative (can only be compared to each other) whereas DCFs are fundamental models in that they can compare an expected cashflow return to the one provided by the risk free rate provided by T-bills

@tayvano_ @KyleSamani - as close as you can get to unbiased + sharp, clear, insightful analysis + constantly providing value for free.

@KyleSamani Also, the argument for starting with MoE seems to be an even stronger defence of a stablecoin hypothesis rather than utility (although this is arguably a subset of utility as stability is a kind of utility).

@KyleSamani To be valuable/secure, utility crypto networks must achieve widespread usage and to achieve widespread usage, they must be valuable/secure. SoV crypto networks don't really face this issue since as you point out, their value accrual dynamics don't rely on widespread usage.

@KyleSamani However, in order to achieve widespread usage, it needs to be valuable since the value is directly related to security, which is the primary reason to use blockchain over something else. This creates somewhat of a chicken and egg effect for utility crypto networks.

@KyleSamani Great thoughts as always and I agree with pmuch all of it. The problem I see with the utility thesis and trying to bootstrap a MOE is that, due to velocity, it needs to achieve much more widespread usage in order to actually accrue value.

@ricburton A few examples of other ERC-20 tokens that are bought back and burned are Binance, Factom and Iconomi, although ICN has restructured as a security token as I think they were advised token burns qualify as a security (a few lawyers we spoke to here in Europe have said the same)

@ricburton Imo the only difference between dividends and buy back and burns is the mechanism by which tokenholders receive cashflows. In the former, they receive a lump sum directly whereas in the latter the sum is received as an increase in the value of the holdings.

@ricburton I'd actually say it's closer to a dividend than a share buyback. A share buyback is an investment (the company is purchasing an asset it can later resell) whereas a token burn is a direct cashflow distribution to tokenholders, similar to what a dividend is to shareholders.
@Travis_Kling @_prestwich Great article, cheers for sharing.

Not only is this super ambitious in itself as it requires overcoming the chicken and egg problem and bootstrapping network effects from scratch, it also puts them in direct competition with the likes of BTC, ETH, ZEC, XMR, DCR, etc.

Any utility token that needs to be valued using an equation of exchange variant is dependent on achieving non-sovereign Store of Value status in order to combat the velocity problem accrue any sort of meaningful value.

What's a good token model? I believe all good token models share the characteristic that they produce some yield and can be valued using a DCF. This applies to staking models (ETH), work tokens (REP or STEEM) and discount tokens (Sweetbridge).

What we should learn from 2017 is that token design cannot be an afterthought - a payment token tacked on to a project that would function fine with FIAT, BTC/ETH or a stablecoin. There must be a reason for users to STORE value in the token, not just transact in and out of it
That said, this does not equal the end of ICO's, it means the end of ICO's with poorly designed, high-velocity payment token models that will never accrue value. Crucially, THIS IS NOT ALL ICO'S.

My thoughts on the "ICO's are dead" narrative: 

I believe most (ie >99%) of ICO's launched in the last 2 yrs will never surpass their ICO valuation, with majority going to 0. Given the amount of money raised (~$15B by some counts), this is a large amount of value destruction
